00020     
00021     /**
00022      *  Execute a single command remotely using ssh and 
00023      * display its output, optionally returning its exit 
00024      * status (like passthru)
00025      *
00026      *  This function is intended to be used as a one-time
00027      * all-at-once non-interactive execution mechanism which
00028      * will run the command remotely and display its output.
00029      *
00030      *  If you try to issue an interactive command using this
00031      * function, all you will get is unneccessary trouble. So
00032      * don't!
00033      *
00034      *  This might be done as well using a pipe on /tmp and
00035      * making the command 'cat' the pipe: when ssh runs, it
00036      * runs the command 'cat' on the pipe and hangs on read.
00037      *  Then we just need a thread to open the pipe, put the
00038      * password and close the pipe.
00039      *  This other way the password is never wirtten down.
00040      * But, OTOH, the file life is so ephemeral that most
00041      * of the time it will only exist in the internal system
00042      * cache, so this approach is not that bad either.
00043      *
00044      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the command, in
00045      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00046      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00047      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00048      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00049      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00050      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00051      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00052      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00053      *  @param command  The command to execute on the remote end
00054      *                      NOTE: if you want to use redirection, the
00055      *                      entire remote command line should be 
00056      *                      enclosed in additional quotes!
00057      *  @param status   Optional, this will hold the termination
00058      *                      status of SSH after invocation, which
00059      *                      should be the exit status of the remote
00060      *                      command or 255 if an error occurred
00061      *  @return void
00062      */
00063     function ssh_passthru($remote, $password, $command, &$status)
00064     {
00065         global $debug;
00066 
00067         // Setup environment
00068         umask(0077);
00069         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh-');
00070         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00071         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname."\n";
00072         
00073         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00074         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00075 
00076         // make askpass command
00077         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00078         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00079         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00080         fclose($fp);
00081         // go
00082         if (isset($status))
00083             passthru("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $status);
00084         else
00085             passthru("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command");
00086     }
00087     
00088     /**
00089      *  Execute a remote command using SSH
00090      *
00091      *  This function sort of mimics rexec(3) using SSH as the transport
00092      * protocol.
00093      *
00094      *  The function returns the exit status of the remote command, and
00095      * appends the remote job output to an optional argument.
00096      *
00097      *  This function is intended to be used as a one-time
00098      * all-at-once non-interactive execution mechanism which
00099      * will run the command remotely and return its output.
00100      *
00101      *  If you try to issue an interactive command using this
00102      * function, all you will get is unneccessary trouble. So
00103      * don't!
00104      *
00105      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the command, in
00106      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00107      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00108      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00109      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00110      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00111      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00112      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00113      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00114      *  @param command  The command to execute on the remote end
00115      *                      NOTE: if you want to use redirection, the
00116      *                      entire remote command line should be 
00117      *                      enclosed in additional quotes!
00118      *  @param output   Optional, the collated (stdout+stderr) output 
00119      *                      of the remote command.
00120      *  @return status  will hold the termination
00121      *                      status of SSH after invocation, which
00122      *                      should be the exit status of the remote
00123      *                      command or 255 if an error occurred
00124      */
00125     function ssh_exec($remote, $password, $command, &$out)
00126     {
00127         global $debug;
00128 
00129         umask(0077);
00130         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh');
00131         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00132         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00133 
00134         putenv('DISPLAY=none:0.');
00135         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00136         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00137         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00138         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00139         fclose($fp);
00140         exec("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $out, $retval);
00141 
00142     }

00144     /**
00145      *  Copy a file or directory from one source to a destination
00146      *
00147      *  This function copies source to dest, where one of them is a
00148      * local filespec and the other a remote filespec of the form
00149      * [user@]host:path
00150      *
00151      *  If the original source is a directory, it will be copied
00152      * recursively to destination (hence easing file transfers).
00153      *
00154      *  The function returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.
00155      *
00156      *  @param origin   The origin path, of the form
00157      *                  [user@][host][:port]path
00158      *                  You may omit the optional sections if
00159      *                  the default values (local username, local
00160      *                  host, standard SSH port) are OK
00161      *
00162      *  @param destination      The destination path, of the form
00163      *                  [user@][host][:port]path
00164      *                  You may omit the optional sections if
00165      *                  the default values (local username, local
00166      *                  host, standard SSH port) are OK
00167      *
00168      *  @parm password  The password to use to connect to the remote
00169      *                  end of the copy (be it the origin or the
00170      *                  destination, it's all the same). If connection
00171      *                  is automatic by some means (.shosts or RSA/DSA
00172      *                  authentication) then it should be ignored and
00173      *                  any password should do.
00174      *
00175      *  @return status  TRUE if all went well, or FALSE on failure.
00176      */
00177     function ssh_copy($origin, $destination, $password)
00178     {
00179         global $debug;
00180 
00181         umask(0077);
00182         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh");
00183         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00184         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00185         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00186         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00187         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00188         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00189         fclose($fp);
00190         system("scp -pqrC $origin $destination", $status);
00191         if ($status == 0)
00192             return TRUE;
00193         else
00194             return FALSE;
00195     }

00197     /**
00198      *  Open an SSH connection to a remote site with a shell to run 
00199      * interactive commands
00200      *
00201      *  Connects to a remote host and opens an interactive shell session
00202      * with NO controlling terminal.
00203      *
00204      *  Returns a process_control array which contains the process resource
00205      * ID and an the standard file descriptors which the caller may use to
00206      * interact with the remote shell.
00207      *
00208      *  @param remote   The remote end to run the shell, in
00209      *                      the form 'user@host:port' (you may
00210      *                      omit the 'user@' or ':port' parts
00211      *                      if the default values [i.e. same user
00212      *                      or standard port] are OK).
00213      *  @param password The remote password. Note that if direct
00214      *                      RSA/DSA/.shosts/.rhosts login is enabled
00215      *                      then the password should be ignored as
00216      *                      SSH should not run the ASKPASS command).
00217      */
00218     function ssh_open_shell($remote, $password)
00219     {   
00220         global $debug;
00221 
00222         // Open a child process with the 'proc_open' function. 
00223         //
00224         // Some tricks: we must open the connection using '-x' to disable
00225         // X11 forwarding, and use '-t -t' to avoid SSH generating an error
00226         // because we are not connected to any terminal.
00227         //
00228         // NOTE: if the web server is trusted remotely (i.e. it's SSH public 
00229         // key is accepted in ~user@host:.ssh/authorized_keys) then any 
00230         // password will do.
00231 
00232         // Prepare I/O
00233         $descriptorspec = array(
00234             0 => array("pipe", "r"),  // connect child's stdin to the read end of a pipe
00235             1 => array("pipe", "a"),  // connect child's stdout to the write end of a pipe
00236             2 => array("pipe", "a")   // stderr is a pipe to read from
00237         );
00238 
00239         // prepare password
00240         umask(0077);
00241         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh");
00242         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00243         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00244 
00245         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00246         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00247         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00248         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00249         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00250         fclose($fp);
00251 
00252         if ($debug) echo "ssh -x -t -t $remote<br />\n";
00253         $process = proc_open("ssh -x -t -t $remote", 
00254                          $descriptorspec,
00255                          $pipes);
00256         
00257         // check status
00258         if (!is_resource($process)) 
00259         {
00260             letal("SSH::connect", "cannot connect to the remote host");
00261             return;
00262         }
00263         if ($debug) echo "proc_open done<br />\n";
00264 
00265         // $pipes now looks like this:
00266         //   0 => writeable handle connected to child stdin
00267         //   1 => readable handle connected to child stdout
00268         //   2 => readable handle connected to child stderr
00269         
00270         // Should we leave this to the user?
00271         // set to non-blocking and avoid having to call fflush
00272         stream_set_blocking($pipes[0], FALSE);
00273         stream_set_blocking($pipes[1], FALSE);
00274         stream_set_blocking($pipes[2], FALSE);
00275         stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[0], 0);
00276         stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[1], 0);
00277         stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[2], 0);
00278 
00279         // We now have a connection to the remote SSH
00280         // Server which we may use to send commands/receive output
00281         $p = array('process' => $process
00282                     ,'std_in' => $pipes[0]
00283                     ,'std_out' => $pipes[1]
00284                     ,'std_err' => $pipes[2] 
00285                    );
00286         if ($debug)  {
00287             echo "process descriptor array is \n";
00288             print_r($p);
00289             /*
00290             fwrite($p['std_in'], "\n");
00291             fwrite($p['std_in'], "touch touche\n");
00292             fwrite($p['std_in'], "logout\n");
00293             fflush($p['std_in']);
00294             fclose($p['std_in']); fclose($p['std_out']); fclose($p['std_err']);
00295             echo "pipes closed\n";
00296             proc_close($p['process']);
00297             echo "process closed\n";
00298         } 
00299         if ($debug == "CHANGE ME") {
00300             echo "process "; print_r($process); echo "\n";
00301             echo "p->process "; print_r($p['process']); echo "\n";
00302             fwrite($pipes[0], "touch touche\n");
00303             fwrite($pipes[0], "logout\n");
00304             fflush($pipes[0]);
00305             fclose($pipes[0]); fclose($pipes[1]); fclose($pipes[2]);
00306             proc_close($process);
00307             */
00308         }
00309         return $p;
00310     }

00312     /**
00313      *  Open an SSH connection to run an interactive command on a remote
00314      * site
00315      *
00316      *  Connects to a remote host and runs an interactive command
00317      * with NO controlling terminal.
00318      *
00319      *  Returns a process_control array which contains the process resource
00320      * ID and an the standard file descriptors which the caller may use to
00321      * interact with the remote shell.
00322      */
00323     function ssh_open_command($remote, $password, $command)
00324     {   
00325         global $debug;
00326 
00327         // Open a child process with the 'proc_open' function. 
00328         //
00329         // Some tricks: we must open the connection using '-x' to disable
00330         // X11 forwarding, and use '-t -t' to avoid SSH generating an error
00331         // because we are not connected to any terminal.
00332         //
00333         // NOTE: if the web server is trusted remotely (i.e. it's SSH public 
00334         // key is accepted in ~user@host:.ssh/authorized_keys) then any 
00335         // password will do.
00336 
00337         // Prepare I/O
00338         umask(0077);
00339         if ($debug) {
00340             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-1-");
00341             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-".getmypid()."-2-");
00342         } else {
00343             $child_stdout = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00344             $child_stderr = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00345         }
00346         $descriptorspec = array(
00347             0 => array("pipe", "r"),  // connect child's stdin to the read end of a pipe
00348             1 => array("pipe", "a"),  // connect child's stdout to the write end of a pipe
00349             2 => array("pipe", "a")   // stderr is a pipe to read from
00350             #1 => array("file", $child_stdout, "a"),
00351             #2 => array("file", $child_stderr, "a")
00352         );
00353 
00354         // prepare password
00355         umask(0077);
00356         $tmpfname = tempnam("/tmp", "phpSsh-");
00357         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00358         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname . "\n";
00359 
00360         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00361         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00362         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00363         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00364         fputs($fp, "rm $tmpfname\n");
00365         fclose($fp);
00366 
00367         if ($debug) echo "ssh -x -t -t $remote $command<br />\n";
00368         $process = proc_open("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", 
00369                          $descriptorspec,
00370                          $pipes);
00371         
00372         // check status
00373         if (!is_resource($process)) 
00374         {
00375             letal("SSH::connect", "cannot connect to the remote host");
00376             return;
00377         }
00378         if ($debug) echo "proc_open done<br />\n";
00379 
00380         // $pipes now looks like this:
00381         //   0 => writeable handle connected to child stdin
00382         //   1 => readable handle connected to child stdout
00383         //   2 => readable handle connected to child stderr
00384         
00385         // Should we leave this to the user?
00386         // set to non-blocking and avoid having to call fflush
00387         stream_set_blocking($pipes[0], FALSE);
00388         stream_set_blocking($pipes[1], FALSE);
00389         #stream_set_blocking($pipes[2], FALSE);
00390         stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[0], 0);
00391         stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[1], 0);
00392         #stream_set_write_buffer($pipes[2], 0);
00393 
00394         // We now have a connection to the remote SSH
00395         // Server which we may use to send commands/receive output
00396         $p = array('process' => $process
00397                     ,'std_in' => $pipes[0]
00398                     ,'std_out' => $pipes[1]
00399                     ,'std_err' => $pipes[2] 
00400                    );
00401         if ($debug)  {
00402             echo "process descriptor array is \n";
00403             print_r($p);
00404         }
00405         return $p;
00406     }

00408     /**
00409      * Close an SSH interactive session
00410      */
00411     function ssh_close($p)
00412     {
00413         global $debug;
00414         
00415             fwrite($p['std_in'], "\n");
00416             fwrite($p['std_in'], "logout\n");
00417             fflush($p['std_in']);
00418             fclose($p['std_in']); fclose($p['std_out']); fclose($p['std_err']);
00419             if ($debug) echo "pipes closed\n";
00420             return proc_close($p['process']);
00421             if ($debug) echo "process closed\n";
00422     }
00423     
00424     /**
00425      *  Execute a remore command and keep an unidirectional stream
00426      * contact with it.
00427      *
00428      *  This routine mimics 'popen()' but uses ssh to connect to
00429      * a remote host and run the requested command.
00430      */
00431     function ssh_popen($remote, $password, $command, $mode)
00432     {
00433         global $debug;
00434 
00435         // Setup environment
00436         umask(0077);
00437         $tmpfname = tempnam('/tmp', 'phpSsh-');
00438         chmod($tmpfname, 0700);
00439         if ($debug) echo $tmpfname."\n";
00440         
00441         putenv("DISPLAY=none:0.");
00442         putenv("SSH_ASKPASS=$tmpfname");
00443 
00444         // make askpass command
00445         $fp = fopen($tmpfname, "w");
00446         fputs($fp, "#!/bin/sh\necho $password\n");
00447         fputs($fp, "rm -f $tmpfname\n");
00448         fclose($fp);
00449         // go
00450         return popen("ssh -x -t -t $remote $command", $mode);
00451     }
00452     
00453     function ssh_pclose($f)
00454     {
00455         return pclose($f);
00456     }
